currentDoc:
Should Schools Provide Free Pads and Tampons?

Have you ever experienced period shaming, or “period poverty”? Should schools step in to help? Should schools be required to provide free pads and tampons to students? How are pads and tampons similar to toilet paper, soap, Band-Aids and other products that are already provided in schools? How are they different?

In my opinion,

How are pads and tampons similar to toilet paper, soap, Band-Aids and other products that are already provided in schools? How are they different?

---

In my opinion, I’d support efforts to provide feminine hygiene products in schools. Feminine hygiene products are necessary. They’re part of a basic need, like food and shelter. Some students might not know what to do if they need one. They might feel alone and isolated and not know who to ask. Having them in a vending machine is not good enough. They should be easily accessible to all students at no charge. Some students just can't afford to buy them. They are at risk of embarrassing situations. How are pads and tampons similar to toilet paper, soap, Band-Aids and other products that are already provided in schools? How are they different?

---

In my opinion, I’d support efforts to provide feminine hygiene products in schools. Feminine hygiene products are necessary. They’re part of a basic need, like food and shelter. Some students might not know what to do if they need one. They might feel alone and isolated and not know who to ask. Having them in a vending machine is not good enough. They should be easily accessible to all students at no charge. Some students just can't afford to buy them. They are at risk of embarrassing situations. Having them available and easily accessible gives students peace of mind. They might be less likely to opt out of sports and other activities because they’ll be more comfortable but having them provided to students for free increases their likelihood of participating in sports and group activities. They need to be easily accessible and conveniently located.=

How are pads and tampons similar to toilet paper, soap, Band-Aids and other products that are already provided in schools? How are they different?

---

In my opinion, I’d support efforts to provide feminine hygiene products in schools. Feminine hygiene products are necessary. They’re part of a basic need, like food and shelter. Some students might not know what to do if they need one. They might feel alone and isolated and not know who to ask. Having them in a vending machine is not good enough. They should be easily accessible to all students at no charge. Some students just can't afford to buy them. They are at risk of embarrassing situations. Having them available and easily accessible gives students peace of mind. They might be less likely to opt out of sports and other activities because they’ll be more comfortable but having them provided to students for free increases their likelihood of participating in sports and group activities. They need to be easily accessible and conveniently located, and offer privacy and discretion.  Students should feel empowered and independent when it comes to feminine hyg

Have you ever experienced period shaming, or “period poverty”? Should schools step in to help? Should schools be required to provide free pads and tampons to students? How are pads and tampons similar to toilet paper, soap, Band-Aids and other products that are already provided in schools? How are they different?

---

In my opinion, I’d support efforts to provide feminine hygiene products in schools. Feminine hygiene products are necessary. They’re part of a basic need, like food and shelter. Some students might not know what to do if they need one. They might feel alone and isolated and not know who to ask. Having them in a vending machine is not good enough. They should be easily accessible to all students at no charge. Some students just can't afford to buy them. They are at risk of embarrassing situations. Having them available and easily accessible gives students peace of mind. They might be less likely to opt out of sports and other activities because they’ll be more comfortable but having them provided to students for free increases their likelihood of participating in sports and group activities. They need to be easily accessible and conveniently located, and offer privacy and discretion.  Students should feel empowered and independent when it comes to feminine hygiene product use.
